text: welcome to the AWS innovate online conference my name is Luke Anderson and
I'm part of the storage business development team today I'm going to be talking about AWS services for data
migration I'd like to start with an overview of the storage services we have
available in AWS as you can see we have block file and object store offerings in
the center of the screen for block storage there's Amazon elastic block store which I referred to as EBS for the
remainder of this presentation EBS provides block storage for ec2 instances running inside of AWS for file
storage we have Amazon Elastic filesystem which are referred to as EFS for the remainder of this presentation
EFS is our NFS based scalable file system that provides file services via
NFS to workloads that are running inside of AWS and with one of our recent releases we provide the capability to
connect your own data center file systems to EFS and we'll talk about that a little bit later in the presentation
and then at the bottom of the circle we have Amazon s3 and Amazon Glacia that
are referred to these as s3 and glacier for the remainder of this presentation s3 in Galatia our AWS is object storage
offerings that are foundational to moving workloads in to AWS including large datasets and used in building
things like data Lakes and compliance archives Amazon s3 offers a range of
storage classes designed for different use cases there are four highly durable storage classes including Amazon s3
standard for general purpose storage or frequently accessed data Amazon s3
standard infrequent access or Amazon s3 one Zone in freaking access for
long-lived but less frequently accessed data and finally Amazon Glacia for long term
archive the AWS objects 2 offerings provide 11 lines of durability which
means if you store and 10 million objects with Amazon s3 you can on average expect to incur a loss of a
single object once every 10,000 years so we're going to focus on today is the AWS
Storage Gateway or Storage Gateway the Amazon EFS file sync service or EFS file
sync we launched back in November as well as Amazon s3 transfer acceleration and
finally the AWS snow services as you start to think about moving to the cloud
migrating your data application and workloads it is good to understand when many companies are doing this today
first to have infrastructure that is more cost effective by only paying for what you're using and not having to go
the traditional route that we've seen with storage arrays in the past or even compute in the past where organizations
try to guess what they're going to need in the future say 24 36 or 48 months out and then buy
it all upfront which means from a storage perspective you're paying a lot of money for capacity that you're not
storing data on because you've bought many years worth of storage albeit over
time the cost per gig is going to go down but upfront it's fairly expensive and there's a lot of heavy lifting that
you have to do to put that infrastructure in place plus you're playing for facilities power and cooling
to have that surplus capacity sitting idle in your environment by not having to worry or spend time capacity planning
and procuring your infrastructure you create productivity gains in your workforce this is coupled with the
agility and elasticity benefits of moving into the cloud and being able to add new instances or add more storage on
demand creates capacity in your workplace AWS lets you quickly spin up resources as you need them deploying
hundreds or even thousands of servers in minutes this means you can very quickly develop and roll out new applications
and it means teams can experiment and innovate more quickly and frequently if an experiment fails you can always deep
revision those servers without risk so in moving data into AWS there are some
things you need to think about upfront planning upfront is critical to enable the best experience for your end-users
and your customers while every cloud adoption journey is unique all require a data migration step which can be
hindered by blockers the first is we want to think about things like disruption from migrating a data center
or application or workload that can impact your customers and internal stakeholders for instance if you are
migrating a file share you want to ensure dependent news have been notified and aware of the change next the speed for how quickly
you can get the data there and we'll cover that a little bit later certainly the costs associated with
migrating data especially if you have to put in additional network circuits to be able to move the data upfront very
quickly or you do a bulk data move last but by no means least are things like
cloud compatibility you want to make sure that your applications are going to run correctly and that you're not going
to have any issues so five key questions to ask yourself before you start to
migrate data the first thing is what kind of data is it where are you going to put it we have database objects and
file block endpoints so you have a lot of options to choose from and you want to make sure that you're getting the
data in the right optimal place for example if you're moving a database that's a sequel database you might be
able to move it directly into one of a WSS manage database offerings then you don't actually have to migrate the
application that's running that database you could just move the database and have it run and be managed and protected
on AWS without having to refactor the tool so we want to make sure we get the
right data the next question to ask is are you going to do this one time is it
one large migration or is it ongoing are you going to continue to replicate data in we certainly have a lot of customers
that move data in on a continuous basis and they're processing it inside of AWS they're getting their to their desired
results much faster because they can spin up more ec2 instances as required or use services like Amazon EMR to
process all of the data in a rapid fashion the next question is this a
one-way migration or is it going to be bi-directional if you're doing a data center migration into AWS then that's a
one-way as you're moving all the data and it's going to live inside of AWS if it's bi-directional that means you're
going to be moving data into and out of AWS on a regular basis and example is
that we have customers that maintain research environments on-premise so if you think about a biotech or a
pharmaceutical company you have chemists scientists and researchers all generating large amounts of data
and moving that data up into AWS then they're processing it inside of AWS
maybe on ec2 Amazon EMR or other AWS analytic services and then the results
are getting saved back into s3 to be read back onto their own premise applications and instruments number four
how much data and time do you have this goes back to what the network looks like if you're going to do a continuous
migration or a one-time migration and how much data do you need to move at a time and what's the time frame for when
you start to when you want to be up and running inside of AWS the last question
is about the WAN the wide area network if you're running over a direct connect and running over the public Internet
you'll probably have an MPLS circuit and coming in via VPN you want to think
about network connectivity between your data center and AWS but is going to affect the four other questions in this
list because if the wine isn't large enough and you have a very tight time frame and a lot of data you might start
running into issues trying to transfer that over the network the good news is that AWS has tools that can help you
manage that process and we'll cover that later I want to talk for a minute about
AWS direct commit AWS Direct Connect or direct connect is a way for you to
connect your data center or your large regional offices or remote offices into the AWS infrastructure wide debt via
dedicated connections with Direct Connect you get one gigabit 10 gigabit
or multiples of 10 gigabit links with a direct connection you're not going over the public internet you're going over a
private network and this is going to give you the lowest latency possible I say possible because you can't overcome
the speed of light or distance but you can get a little bit better control about the path the data is taking over
the network for example you gain some efficiencies by reducing the amount of packet loss and congestion that you'll
typically see going over the Internet with Direct Connect you get a secure high performance connection into AWS
that many of our customers are using today the next thing we're going to talk
about is the AWS Sno services the AWS Sno services are made up of AWS snowball
aw snowball edge an AWS snowmobile with the AWS snowball you get 80 terabytes of
capacity 10 gigabit network connection and when you copy data and write data into AWS snowball and the AWS snowball
edge the data is going to be compressed and encrypted an important thing to note
is that the encryption key doesn't travel with the device that means you keep control of the encryption and the
data you control the writing of the data to the device and once we get the device back we're going to verify that it
hasn't been tampered with we're using established external tamper checks we're also going to verify that the operating
system and everything electronically about the device is secure and hasn't been tampered with once that has
completed successfully we're going to copy all of that data into your s3 bucket so with the AWS snowball edge you
have 100 terabytes of capacity and we have 10 25 and 40 gigabit network
connections you also have the ability to write to the AWS snowball edge via NFS
clients and it also has its own s3 like API so if you have an application in
your data center that supports s3 API you can write directly to the AWS snowball edge using that with the
traditional snowball you have a client that acts as an s3 API which can copy the data and write it into the snowball
for you on the far right of the slide we have the AWS snowmobile this is our
exabyte scale device when you order the AWS snowmobile will drive at your data center you plug it in you fill it up
with data and then we'll drive it back and load all of that data into your s3 environment inside of AWS so the AWS
know services are a way that you can move large amounts of data without having to saturate your one or if you
have a location where the wine quality isn't that great you could send an AWS snowball or AWS snowball edge there the
thing to remember is when you're moving large amounts of data and you need to do it quickly the AWS know services are a
way for you for you to be able to do that to get the process started is pretty
straightforward you log into the console and create a new job we will then ship the device to you you
receive it you unlock it and you plug it into your network and then you fill it up with data and then ship it back to AWS and
again after we verified that everything looks good and secure we'll then copy that data into your s3 bucket the next
thing we're going to talk about is Amazon EFS file sync with EFS file sync you can move data from your file systems
inside your data center or your regional offices into Amazon EFS file system and you can do it very quickly very easily
and securely as everything is encrypted end-to-end as you're moving the data how
it works is that you deploy sync agent inside of your data center or your regional office this sync agent runs in
a virtual machine as seen on the left-hand side of the slide the virtual machine connects via NFS to your file
server or nas device then you'll have an NFS export of a file system that you can copy in its entirety or you can connect
directly to a subdirectory and just move this subdirectory to EFS once the
connection is established we'll move all the required data off into AWS again we do that over an encrypted connection
that is also compressed prior to transfer we do this using multiple TCP
flows with an AWS developed TCP stack that has been tuned for high throughput and to be able to deal with things like
packet loss and packet out of orders typically things you're going to see if you're going over a VPN connection over
the Internet this enables you to get the highest possible performance when migrating those file systems and now
let's see this in action so we start the demo with two amazon EFS environments created in u.s. East one and us East two
now this could also be with an on-premise NFS filesystem connecting to an Amazon EFS filesystem the amazon EFS
file sync agent has be deployed onto an ec2 instance so we're going to create a sync task in the higher region we
capture the DNS name for the source file system and enter that in then we specify
a source mount point and in this case slash source and then choose the agent
required which is the ohio region and now we go and perform the same tasks for
the destination where we select the mount point in this
case is slash destination in the sync
settings you can select whether you preserve some of the metadata for example ownership permissions and
whether you want to keep consistency between the source and destination file systems now we name the sync set Ohio to
Virginia we can now see this being
created once we've refreshed we can see
the sync set will be available now we go up to actions and we start the sync task
between our higher and North Virginia the status will say starting and then
we'll start to move to a percentage complete as we move through there are multiple stages to this once it's
working through it will start performing a verify and then it will say completed at the end now let's just check the
history tab to make sure the 17 files have been migrated to the cross as we
can see the best way to check this let's just log into the systems we're on the source system at the moment with check
that we're in a source directory we do a quick DF to check the file systems and
then we're gonna do a list to see the 17 files that we have in our source now
we're going to perform the same commands across on the destination file system
again we'll check our current directory check the file systems and then finally
we'll do a listing just to see that we have actually migrated and synchronized the 17 files across and preserved the
permissions and sizing the next thing we'll talk about is Amazon s3 transfer
acceleration Amazon s3 transfer acceleration is a way to improve performance when you're writing data to
or reading data from s3 buckets that may be far away so in this slide you can see
we've got an s3 bucket inside us East one on the east coast of the United States and we have a client in India who
is loading data into an s3 bucket doing it the traditional way you'll be going over
the internet where you'll have high latency as you're going over long distance and going over the Internet in
this scenario you're also highly susceptible to packet loss and packet out of orders which is all going to
reduce the performance so even if you have a one gigabit network you're probably only going to average about
four megabits per second and have hundreds of milliseconds of latency even if you have as little as one tenth of
one percent packet loss it's going to dramatically slow down the performance so s3 transfer acceleration is a way for
you to get around those issues of going over the Internet the way it works is the client makes a connection to one of
AWS is edge locations that is part of the global Amazon network in this case
they're connected to an edge location that's inside of India so now instead of connection that is hundreds of
milliseconds is significantly reduced the date restore native occasion and
then transferred over the Amazon network where we had no packet loss we can manage congestion as well as do things
like manage the window size for TCP and take advantage of the bandwidth available all of this is automatically
performed and there's no software required you simply enable it for the s3 bucket via your console and then at s3
transfer acceleration into the URL for the bucket all of this as with other AWS
services is documented in your online user documentation as discussed in a
previous slide we've seen customers experience up to one hundred and seventy-one percent improvement in transfer speed by using s3 transfer
exhilaration and as you can see the further away you are the better the Delta and performance now for a customer
use case for s3 transfer acceleration huddle is a software provider that offers video and analytics platform for
coaches and athletes to quickly review game footage to improve team play the
web based system serves youth amateur and professional teams in football basketball soccer volleyball and other
popular sports the problem statement is that on a typical Friday during the football season more than 35 hours of
video is uploaded every minute they implemented s3 transfer acceleration to
prove the upload speed for coaches after their sessions and they saw 20% increase in upload speeds you can find out more
details on the AWS site under case studies for huddle next we're going to
talk about the AWS Storage Gateway family the AWS Storage Gateway family
enables you to build hybrid storage solutions when you're connecting infrastructure applications and servers
inside your data center to AWS this enables you to take advantage of the durability and low cost of s3 the low
cost archiving capabilities of Grecia and the data protection of things like Amazon EBS snapshots for volumes of data
that's running inside of your own datacenter we break down the AWS Storage Gateway
into three modes so on the left hand side you see that we support files volumes and tapes on the right hand side
you see that we support targets such as s3 glacier and EBS snapshots an
important thing to note about the AWS Storage Gateway family is that all modes support AWS cloud watch AWS cloud trail
AWS I am for security management and AWS kms for encryption so if you're using
AWS today the same tools you use to manage and operate your AWS environment can be used with the AWS Storage Gateway
the first thing we'll talk about is the file gateway the file gateway provides
an on-premise file storage solution that's running on a virtual machine inside of your data center it's
exporting NFS version 3 and version 4.1 which means that your Linux and UNIX workloads and also some of your Windows
workloads can connect we then have an HTTPS connection back to the storage gateway infrastructure in AWS that
connects to s/3 s/3 and frequent access as well as Glacia through lifecycle policies so when you connect the file
gateway virtual machine to an s3 bucket you can have up to 10 buckets connected to that virtual machine for the file
gateway so each bucket becomes an NFS mount point that enables you to choose where you write data into and whether it
lands on s3 standard or s3 and frequent access and then enables you to take advantage of the lifecycle policies
so with all the flexibility you have with an s3 bucket today you've got with the file gateway because all the fall
gateway is doing is presenting an NFS export or NFS mount point to that s3 bucket it's important to know that all
of these storage gateway modes provide a caching layer where you can have up to 16 terabytes of cache for a virtual
machine which means that any data that writes to the storage gateway is going to be stored locally in cache this
enables you to get a fast response back to the application server then in parallel the virtual machine is going to
start streaming the data up into your service in AWS so for example if you
were to write word doc to the file gateway you will see this new s3 bucket as an object named word doc and if
there's a directory structure says users slash Luke slash my Doc's slash word doc will take that directory structure and
will turn that into a prefix for the object when we write it into your bucket so this means you can migrate data from
your application servers inside of your data center put that data in s3 that enables you to perform real-time sequel
queries using amazon athena or process it using amazon EMR now i want to share
a use case with you for the file gateway so this is halliburton landmark services landmark provides services software and
data center applications to companies in the oil and gas industry landmark restoring all field data seismic data
satellite imagery on NASA filers and our archiving into LTO drives and then
sending them to tape off-site for long-term secure storage now when a customer came to landmark and requested
this data landmark would then have to request the tapes back from off-site they then have to restore them onto the
nasa Foilers and once the data is back on premise they'll then provide the application data to Petra Bank which is
their application to their end users only then could the end users access the data requested so how they fixed it of
AWS was first they copied their data to a snowball and shipped it to AWS and then we put it into the s3 bucket they
then deployed a file gateway inside of their data center and connected that to the Petra Bank application to the file
gateway as they were already using NFS to mount that and a spoiler it was a simple
process to migrate the connection to file gateway now they're able to go from days and weeks to restore the data and
make it available to their customers into a real-time self-service model not
only have they been able to reduce this time to data for the customers they have reduced what they were paying for
archiving and managing that archive by up to 90% so next we're going to talk
about the tape gateway from a migration standpoint tape gateway fits into a couple of different use cases and after
I've explained how tape gateway works we'll walk through an end-to-end workflow of how you would migrate data using the tape gateway the tape gateway
presents ten drives 1,500 slots and a robot as part of virtual tape library so
you connect to it via I scuzzy so your system's existing backup software is able to go through and index the library
you then create tapes as they're needed on demand and up to two-and-a-half terabytes per tape one thing that's
important to know about the tape gateway is that when you create tapes you only pay for capacity that's used so you
could go ahead and create a hundred two and a half terabyte tapes barcode them but only write one gigabit of data to
those tapes you would only pay for one gigabyte so as with all AWS services you're only paying for what you're
actually consuming but you can go ahead and create all of those tapes in advance so they already on your backup
application when required so as I mentioned previously the tape gateway also has a local cache with the tape
gateway you can have up to 16 terabytes of cache and what that means is if you're backing up 10 terabytes that
entire backup will fit in cache if you needed to restore data you're restoring directly out of cache at least until you
do the next day's backup all of your data gets stored inside of AWS in the
backend component of the storage gateway however with tape gateway to view the data stored in AWS you have to go
through the storage gateway service as we do compress and encrypt the data before it traverses the network so how
it works at AWS tape gateway is for all data that is written to a tape in the drive that same data is written to s3 so
if the tape is still active in the library that means that inside of the storage guy we're service that date restored in s3
if you export to tape out of the library the data gets life cycle automatically to Glacia as an archive similar to how
you would do this with your traditional backup software so it's the same workflow that you have today for writing
tapes and managing tapes but using AWS as discussed earlier here's a quick
example of a workflow you have a backup server writing backup data to a disk appliance and you have a tape libel or
archiving on premise then you're sending those tapes off-site into a vault for
longer-term archiving first you deploy the tape gateway virtual machine you
connect to the service and configure the backup server to connect to the AWS Storage Gateway by the VTL virtual tape
library now the backups are being written to Amazon s3 and then archived across to Amazon Glacia
you can now stop writing to the tape infrastructure and utilizing the off-site vault typically all of those
old tapes are going to expire at some point over time so you can stop adding to that stack stop buying physical tapes
stop making archive copies or clone copies in short a Priory and keep maybe have to keep your backup disk appliance
because that could be doing things at deduplication and over time your old tape archives are going to start to
expire and as they expire you can take them out of your backup software and out of the off-site storage over time you'll
be able to completely remove all on-premise storage infrastructure and have all of your backups going into the
tape gateway virtual machine so tape gateway provides a mechanism for you to migrate your data out of old archive
into AWS preserving the workflow that you're using today the next thing that
we're going to talk about is the volume gateway the volume gateway is volume Storage presents over I scuzzy we get an
iSCSI LUN just like if you had a SAN storage away just like with tape is compressed and encrypted and sent over
an encrypted connection to AWS it's stored in s3 as a volume and here you can take snapshots using the EBS
snapshot service you get up to 16 terabytes of cache inside of that virtual gateway and we have two modes
with this cache the first mode is cached and with cache mode you get 30
two times thirty-two terabyte longs which represents one petabyte of addressable storage capacity back inside
of the service and you can mount that from any server workstation that supports I scusi and start working with
it the second mode is stored volume mode where we keep a copy of all the data in
on the LUN inside of the virtual machine with the stored volume mode all of the
data is going to be stored in that virtual machine that means all of your writes and reads are going to happen to
and from cache inside of the storage gateway virtual machine and where this
becomes interesting from a migration standpoint is that you can use this to migrate existing data out of your data
center so as you can see on the Left we have an application server where we have
an existing volume where this would be likely mounted over a storage area network to use the Storage Gateway
installed volume mode as a migration tool you would deploy the virtual machine inside your data center then
take that volume you detach it from your application server and you attach it to the storage gateway virtual machine
inside of the storage gateway virtual machine we're not going to rewrite any of the data we won't format it and we're
not going to write a new disk signature everything will stay as it was and your application server is now going to
connect to that LUN via I scuzzy and everything will look as if it did when it was connected natively but now the
storage gateway virtual machine is in the data path next we're going to take that data and we're going to start
bootstrapping it which means we're going to start copying it in aggregate blocks up into the storage gateway service to
create a new volume once the new volume has been created you can take a snapshot and when you take that snapshot this is
where you can migrate that data and that workload up into AWS because once the data is done bootstrapping and we take
our snapshot it is an authoritative copy of your application data we can deploy a
new ec2 instance and in this case a Windows Server we can take that snapshot and as it will be an ABS snapshot which
means we can turn it into an EBS volume we can give it to that server we've just spun up now you can take away other
infrastructure and have all of your data and application server where it's been migrated to up running in AWS with
minimal amount of downtime and the minimal amount of overhead in efforts to actually get the data and the
application running up into ec2 so now to finish up I do want to point out the
